Dear Ms. Johnson:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.

III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12303 Policy and procedures.
Section (2) An agency may not be more restrictive than the department's
Description policies or administrative rules governing licensing and services.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The agency emailed foster parents and indicated there will be four
meetings again as they did in 2023 for a total amount of 8 hours of
mandatory training. However, the policy they had a foster parent
sign about training stated they only had to attend a total of six
hours of training each year and only 3 of those had to be with
MDHHS. In addition to this the fourth and final meetings of 2023,
the foster parent was told if they did not attend the meeting, they
could face a CAP.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant
I had contact with Complainant by email on 1/20/2025; and
1/27/2025. Complainant wanted to maintain anonymity and
indicated they would only communicate on these allegations by
email to protect themselves. Complainant indicated as a foster
parent they signed a policy which indicates they are required to
participate in 3 hours of DHHS (Department of Health and Human
Service) training a year and 6 hours overall. They indicated the
agency sends out quarterly mandatory 2-hour trainings which
would total 8 hours of training to occur specifically with DHHS.
Complainant indicated the email sent out from DHHS about
tomorrow’s (1/21/2025) mandatory 2-hour training, and the email
document sent out to foster parents in 2024 said if foster parents
did not attend they could face having to complete a corrective
action plan (CAP).
Complainant wrote that the agency indicated in the most recent
mandatory meeting this year that as foster parents they have to
attend these quarterly meetings, which are four times a year and
are always 2 hours long. Complainant expressed concern that
these requirements by DHHS are against the rules.
Chief Administrator
On 1/21/2025 I spoke with Chief Administrator about the
allegations onsite. Chief administrator provided copies of licensing
documents
Licensing Supervisor 1
2

On 1/21/2025 I interviewed Licensing Supervisor (LS) 1 about the
allegations onsite. LS 1 reported the agency’s policy does not
require foster parents to obtain 8 hours of training annually. Nor
does it require any additional hours of training other than the 6-
hours that’s required by the rule. She said their agency’s checklist
documents that only 6 hours of training is required annually.
She reported the agency does notify all foster parents via email
that they are mandated to attend all four foster parent training
meetings via DHHS; and that 3 hours of their 6 hours of required
annual training must be completed via DHHS- North Central. She
reported the most recent email to foster parent about this was sent
on 1/8/2025.
LS 1 denied ever telling foster parents verbally or in writing that if
they did not attend the mandatory meetings and training via
DHHS-North Central that the agency would investigate them for a
corrective action plan. She reported the agency had explored
doing the latter internally. That conversations went back and forth
on the matter. She reported on 9/26/2023 they spoke with the
licensing team about that possibility, that if the foster parent did
not comply with attending the mandatory meetings/trainings, the
agency could look at requiring that a corrective action plan be
done. She reported ultimately the matter was left as an open
issue; they never attempted to open a special evaluation on any
foster family for not attending the mandatory meetings.
Licensing Staff
On 1/27/2025, I interviewed Licensing Worker (LW) 1 and
Licensing Supervisor (LS) 2 via Teams. I interviewed Licensing
Worker (LW) 2 and Licensing Worker (LW) 3 via Teams on
2/5/2025.
All four-licensing staff reported information as LS 1 had related to
foster parents only being required to complete 6 hours of training
per year, with 3 hours being mandatory via DHHS North Central.
Each staff person reported some clarifying statements:
Licensing Worker 1 denied personally telling a foster parent or
hearing of anyone telling a foster parent that if they did not attend
a mandatory meeting they will be required to complete a
corrective action plan. She reported the mandatory foster parent
meetings are not always four times a year and foster parents are
not penalized if they do not attend them. She reported the
meetings are not really mandatory. It is just their way of
encouraging and motivating foster parents to get their required
number of training hours.
3

Licensing Supervisor 2 reported the foster parent meetings are
offered four times a year and each session is 2 hours. He reported
foster parents do not have to attend all 4 sessions. They do have
to get 3 hours of their training via DHHS- North Central, but they
also encourage foster parents to obtain training via other sources.
LS 2 reported foster parents could have a special evaluation and
corrective action plan open against them for not attending one of
the mandatory meeting, LS reported there was a discussion on
this matter sometime after he started with North Central (July of
2024) and he discussed this with his staff in August or September
of 2024. Staff were to advise foster parents that since they had
signed the agency’s policies, and foster parent agency agreement,
they were required to get the 3 hours of training via DHHS- North
Central.
Licensing Worker 2 reported the agency offers trainings every
second Tuesday of the month and there are mandatory foster
parent meetings held every three months. She indicated these
meetings/training enable foster parents to get the training they
need. LW 2 reported although their email to foster parents indicate
it’s a mandatory meeting being held everyone does not show up.
LW 2 also acknowledged there had been a time foster parents
were to be advised that if they did not attend a mandatory meeting
they could be placed on a corrective action plan or have a special
evaluation open against their license. She reported the matter
was never followed up on because the agency had contact with
DCWL and were advised that was not permissible per the rules.
Licensing Worker 3 was not clear as to whether a foster parent
had to attend all of the mandatory foster parent meetings offered
by DHHS North Central or just one of them. She too, recalled a
discussion and possible email to foster parents last year about
foster parents possibly being placed on a corrective action plan for
not attending mandatory foster parent meeting, but she could not
recall when that may have happened.
Document review:
Documents from the Chief Administrator that included:
• A foster home checklist and foster parent training sign off
form that indicated 6-hours of training is required of foster
parents with 3 hours being mandatory via DHHS- North
Central.
• A copy of a 1/8/2025 email to foster parents was also
included. It indicated the agency’s next quarterly mandatory
foster parent meeting is January 21, 2025. That there
4

would be two sessions offered at the agency on that day,
one at 10AM-12PM and another at 6 PM-8 PM. Foster
parents were to respond to the email or to let their licensing
worker know if childcare would be needed.
Copy of a 9/11/2024 email to foster parents announcing a
10/15/2024 foster parent meeting with the agency offering a
10:00am-12 noon or 6:00pm- 8:00pm session. The email
indicated the following:
• The “quarterly MANDATORY foster parent meeting” was
coming up and foster parents were to attend one of the
sessions offered.
• The email reminded foster parents they were expected to
attend each of the mandatory meetings.
• Any foster parent that had not attended a mandatory
meeting in the last year must attend the upcoming meeting
or be at risk of a corrective action plan and/or special
evaluation.
Copy of the agency’s Foster Parent Agency Agreement (DHS-
1798) which showed:
• On page two, the agreement’s number 12 statement that
indicated as a foster parent they agree “To attend foster
parent training when requested to do so by the
department.”
DHHS Policy FOM 922-Foster Family Recruitment, Support and
Development- Ongoing Training which indicates:
• Ongoing training is any training that is offered after the
initial orientation and pre-licensure training.
• Each child placing agency is required to have an annual
training plan.
• Each foster parent must complete at least six hours of
training per calendar year.
• No mandate on where the foster parent’s training must
come from or mandatory foster parent meetings.
Foster Home Licensing rule R 400.9416(1) Foster parent training
which indicates:
• Each licensed foster parent must attend training as
required by the agency’s foster parent training plan, totaling
to at least 6 hours per year.
• No mandate on where the foster parent’s training must
come from or mandatory foster parent meetings.
5

Analysis Based on interviews and document reviewed the evidence
showed the agency’s mandate for foster parents to attend
quarterly meetings, and 3 hours of their training hours via DHHS
North Central, is more restrictive than the department's policies or
administrative rules. The rules do not mandate a foster parent to
complete any number of training hours via their certifying agency.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan continuation of the agency
current license status is recommended.
